dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Through the window of a moving vehicle, we see a series o small, middle-class houses.  This could be any suburban s in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy is seated near the back of a moving bus.  This is T BOWDEN, 15, as All-American as they come.  He stares out other passengers indifferently.  Then something catches h

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Todd pedals his bike down a quiet street and pulls up to unassuming bungalow set far back on its lot.  This is the of house one would hardly notice driving through the peac suburban community of Santo Donato.  Todd gets off his bi heads up the front steps.  On the way, he bends down to p the L.A. Times. Two signs, in laminated plastic, are secured neatly above door bell.  The first reads: "ARTHUR DENKER".  The second "NO SOLICITORS, NO PEDDLERS, NO SALESMEN". Todd RINGS the bell.  Nothing.  He looks at his watch.  I twelve past ten.  He RINGS again, this time longer.  Stil nothing.  Finally, Todd leans on the tiny button, staring watch as he does so.  After more than a minute of SOLID R a voice is heard from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  All right.  I'm coming.  Let it go! Todd lets go as a chain behind the heavy door starts to r Then it opens.  An old man stands behind the screen.  He DUSSANDER, a.k.a. Arthur Denker.  Mid-seventies.  Standin in his bathrobe and slippers, a cigarette smashed in his he looks like a cross between Boris Karloff and Albert Ei Dussander stares at Todd, who tries to speak, but suddenl cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy.  I don't need anything, boy.  Can't you read?  I thought all American boys could read.  Don't be a nuisance, now.  Good day. The door begins to close.  Todd waits till the last momen before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your paper, Mr. Dussander.  The door stops.  Dussander opens it slowly.  He unlatches screen and slips his fingers around the paper.  Todd does let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me my newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Mr. Dussander.  Dussander snatches the paper away and closes the screen d Quickly, almost imperceptibly, the old man's eyes survey area: across the street, up and down the sidewalk, the bo bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Denker.  See? (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denker.  Perhaps you cannot read after all.  What a pity.  Good day.  As the front door closes, Todd speaks rapidly into the na

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bergen-Belsen, January '43 to June '43.  Auschwitz, June '43 to June '44.  Then you went to Patin.  The door stops, still partly open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the war, you escaped to Buenos Aires. From 1950 to '52 you were in Cuba, and  then... From 1952 to '58... I don't know.  No one does.  But in 1965, you popped up in West Berlin, where they almost got you.  The door opens wider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, boy.  I don't know what is the matter  with you.  But I don't have time for this  game.  Now, get out of here before I call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call them if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  The heavy door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay by me Herr Kommandant.  I'm sure the police would love to meet the "Blood- fiend of Patin."  In a flash the front door is open, so is the screen.  Dus is through the doorway and descending upon Todd with the umbrella raised to strike him.  Todd stumbles back agains porch rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get away from this house, God damn you!  I'll beat you all the way home. But Todd regains his composure quickly.  He brushes himse and levels his eyes at the old man who now hardly seems t threat he was a few seconds ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After 1965, no one saw you again... Until I did.  Three weeks ago on the downtown bus. If you want to call the cops, go right ahead. I'II wait on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't?  Listen, old man, if I want to start screaming right here, I will.  If I want to  ride down to the police station and bring the cops back myself, then I will.  I will do what ever I want.  Do you understand? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you like, I could come in for a minute.  We could talk.  Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be out of my mind to let an insane boy like you into my home. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want, to come into my home? So be it.  There is no arguing with crazy people. Dussander turns and steps back through the screen door. stops at the threshold of the house and turns.  He is hol the screen door open with one leg, the front door open wi other.  He looks straight ahead.  A moment later, Todd st into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dussander's home is what you would expect of a single, po man.  Nothing fancy, nothing out of the ordinary.  Todd l around, perhaps half-expecting to find a Nazi flag or an painting of Der Fuehrer hanging above the mantle.  But he doesn't, and moves into the living room where an old pict a woman sits framed on an end table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife.  She died in 1955 of lung disease. At that time I was working at the Menschler Motor Works in Essen.  I was heartbroken.  Todd's attention drifts away and his fingers slip over to lampshade next to the photograph.  He begins to feel it a though he were inspecting it for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that!  Todd jumps back a little but then recovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, wasn't it Ilse Koch who made the lampshades out of human skin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do, Mr. Dussander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denker.  Denker.  Denker.  You don't listen, boy.  The television has fried your brain.  Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hands are shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they're shaking.  I'm old.  We all  shake.  You are most tiresome, and rude.  Now if you have a point I wish you'd come to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in no rush.  If I thought you had  plans, I'd say cancel them, but since I know you don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know nothing of my business --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business?  You sit in that ugly chair and watch soap operas all day.  Except on  Friday afternoons when you walk down to the  movie theater.  And twice a week you take the bus downtown to do your shopping.  You always use the express lane because you never have  more than ten items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been following me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I followed you.  You think I  normally go around to peoples' houses and accuse them of being Nazi fugitives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps for me you made an exception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for you I had to be sure.  For Kurt Dussander I had to be absolutely certain. ...Now, I am, and that's why I'm here.  Todd sits on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I see now.  As I am this ex-Nazi fellow, as you say, then this must be the part where I offer you my hidden stash of gold, taken from the mouths of old Jewish  men, of course, which I keep buried in the  basement.  Isn't that right, boy?  Well, I'm afraid you're wasting your time. I have no  money.  If I did I might even give you some just to be done with this nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need money.  You don't have any  anyway.  At least, I don't think so.  You probably had to spend it all to sneak in the country.  A good American passport is  expensive on the black market, that I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?  Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.  I know it all, Dussander.  You're my One Great Interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My One Great Interest.  Well, not you  personally, but, ...well, it's something I  learned back in eighth grade.  Our teacher, Miss Harmon, she said we'd have to find our One Great Interest in life.  You know, the  thing that would really grab us.  Once we did that, everything would fall into place.  Like hers, she said, wasn't teaching, but  collecting nineteenth-century postcards.  I guess there's no money in that, so she has to  be a teacher.  Anyway, she told us to start thinking about it.  So I did, but nothing happened.  Until the following summer, in  Ronny Pegler's garage.  That's where I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd and RONNY, both 13, rummage through several large bo the corner of the garage.  We see that the boxes are fill old war magazines.  Ronny tosses several of them to the g as he digs for his dad's old copies of Penthouse.  Ronny one Penthouse and rifles through it.  He discards it a mo later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these has three girls doing it at the same time. But the old war magazines catch Todd's attention. He pic up curiously and carefully flips through the tattered pag see a few of the photographs: Nazi storm troopers, priso behind barbed wire, the ovens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it!  Check this out. ...Todd, look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on a sec.  As young Todd stares into this secret world, his voice co in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all there... pictures of stuff I'd never seen, stuff they never put in the books anymore, especially the ones they give us to read. And here were stacks of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd speaks excitedly.  Dussander, very bored, clearly in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It... grabbed me. It was just like Miss Harmon said. I couldn't believe it. But there it was, the camps, the uniforms, the ...the way they saluted each other. But what am I telling you for? You know more about this stuff than anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what are you telling me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then last year I wrote my big term paper on  Dachau.  I got an A+.  It was the only A+ she gave.  I mean I always do real well.  A's on everything.  That's why I'm accelerated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accelerated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, accelerated.  I skipped two grades, second and ninth.  I didn't need them. That's why I'm already a junior.  Dussander sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids resent me for it.  That's not  important.  Anyway, my paper really floored my history teacher.  I guess because I got  through all those books without throwing up. But I learned something.  I learned that when you talk about the camps now, you have to  remember to sound really disgusted.  I mean, you can't just say what happened like the magazines did and leave it at that.  If I  tried that the teacher would have freaked and called my parents in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd sits on one of the boxes surrounded by dozens of the magazines.  The door to the house opens and Ronny, lookin cross, pokes his head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd, your mom's on the phone.  She says you have to come home for dinner.  ...Todd?  Todd, lost in the sea of old photographs, doesn't notice at first.  Then he looks up at him.  In his eyes is a gli darkness that we will come to know better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly wary of Todd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom's on the phone.  ANGLE on Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowadays you have to... soften it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I care about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, I don't want it softened.  Todd hops up and begins to pace the floor. Dussander star him blankly, unsure of where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure you trouble your parents to no end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm pretty low maintenance.  That's what my dad says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told your parents about me, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're crackers, but go on.  I'm riveted. Todd looks deep into Dussander's eyes.  Dussander is uncomfortable.  Slowly, Todd reaches out and brushes his against Dussander's hand.  Dussander gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then it happened... I was on my way to the library.  It was raining...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd's voice narrates what we are seeing.  Todd, seated n back of the bus, watches Dussander climb aboard.  Todd th nothing of it at first, but soon finds that he is unable his eyes off him.  Todd is trying to place the old man's his mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You climbed on the bus and started this slow walk down the aisle.  Just like you were  examining a new batch of inmates.  I don't think anybody gave you a second glance but  me, but somehow ...people seemed to move out of your way.  And under your arm you carried a rolled up umbrella.  But what really did  it, what really set me off was the coat.  You were wearing this long black rain coat.  My mind suddenly flipped back to a picture of you taken at Patin.  You in your S.S.  greatcoat with a riding crop under your arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was incredible.  Dussander stares back at him flatly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of this... because of a rain coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn't that easy. I mean, I had to really check up on it. And every picture of you in those books is forty years old, at least. I went back to the library to find the picture. And then I matched it with the photos I took.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took photographs of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got this little camera.  Fits right in the palm of my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crunches cigarette into ashtray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clever boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But even then I couldn't be sure.  I needed real proof.  So I went to the mall and bought a fingerprint kit from the hobby shop and a book that tells you what you're supposed to look for and then dusted your mailbox while you were at the movies.  Pretty smart, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... put dust on my mailbox?  For  fingerprints?  You took photographs of me?  What else did you do?... I don't believe any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already had a copy of your fingerprints.  They're on your want sheet from the Israeli government.  It's on database at UC Irvine. Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon.  He storms toward the kitchen and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care for a drink, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you got a Coke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Kok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk.  Dussander disappears into the kitchen.  Todd stands alone living room.  He lets out a long, nervous breath, showing for the first the presence of something other than the cold confidence been putting up for Dussander.  He knows he has crossed i dangerous territory from which there is no going back.  B after a moment he composes himself; he has come this far. sternness returns to his eyes.  Todd is all business.  He a breath, and then speaks loudly enough for Dussander to him in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes eight good matches, they're called  compares, actually, for a fingerprint to get  accepted in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd steps up onto the porch and looks around calmly.  He the powder and brush from his pocket and begins to examin mailbox for prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there were two sets of prints.  The  first I figured were the mailman's.  Once I  knew what I was looking for, yours were easy to spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be a detective.  The SOUNDS of a refrigerator opening and closing come fro kitchen.  Drinks being poured.  Todd begins to move slowl toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I will... Mom thinks I'd be good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the doorway just as Dussander turns around wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found fourteen compares.  Dussander approaches him carrying a tumbler of milk and a of bourbon.  He hands the tumbler to Todd, who brings it his lips and hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Gott. He snatches the cup and swallows twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?  It's milk, boy.  From Dairylee Farms.  On the carton is a picture of a smiling cow.  Todd pauses and then begins to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more to himself than Todd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And two missing children. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy what you have done, I have to explain this to you because clearly you don't understand, what you have done is a violation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A violation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like those experiments with the decompression chamber.  Now, that was a violation, Dussander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fucking name.  Enough of that.  I demand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I demand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You demand nothing from me.  Ever.  Get it? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I will tell you this once more, and for  the last time.  My name is Arthur Denker.  It has never been anything else.  It has never even been Americanized.  If you must know, and apparently you must, I was named by my father who greatly admired the stories of Arthur Conan Doyle.  I did serve in the  reserves, I admit, and in the late thirties,  when I was first married, I supported Hitler. I supported him most, I suppose, because for the first time in years there was work and there was tobacco. ...Would you like a  cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  My dad used to smoke.  Mom made him quit.  Now he's addicted to Nicorette... that's nicotine gum.  Dussander turns toward the counter and pulls a kitchen ma from a cabinet.  He lights his cigarette with his back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicotine gum.  Dussander's eyes drift to the collection of kitchen knive neatly stuffed in their block on the counter in front of He lingers a moment, pulls deeply on the cigarette, then and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Hitler lost his mind at the end,  directing phantom armies at the whim of his  astrologer.  He even gave his dog, Blondi, a  death capsule.  On May 2nd, 1945, my regiment surrendered to the Americans.  I remember that a private named Gonzales gave me a chocolate bar.  I wept.  Bored, Todd sinks into a chair at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was interned at Essen where I was treated very well. We listened to the Nuremberg trials on the radio and when Goering committed suicide, I bought half a bottle of schnaps and got drunk. When I was released, I put wheels on cars at the Essen Motor Works until I retired in 1963. In 1967 I emigrated here, to California, and became a U.S. Citizen. I am as American as you are. I vote. No Buenos Aires, no Berlin, no koo-ba
